documents.title: markets mixed on scottish concerns and ukraine hopes
text: it was an uncertain day on european markets , with political concerns continuing to weigh on share prices , writes nick fletcher .
in the uk , a weekend poll showing a majority in scotland in favour of independence dominated the market , with some £ 2.6bn wiped off the value of leading shares with scottish links .
royal bank of scotland - which mitigated the damage with news of its flotation of citizens in the us - ended down 4.5p or £ 513m .
lloyds - not able to follow suit with any corporate developments up its sleeve - dropped by £ 1.28bn .
the uk government , already reeling from the weekend poll results , was looking at a near £ 500m fall in the value of its stakes in the two banks .
in europe , there was a more mixed performance , with talk that sanctions against russia could be deferred helping to support the markets and pulling them back from their worst levels .

the final scores on the doors showed : the ftse 100 finished down 20.33 points or 0.3 % at 6834.77 germany 's dax edged up 0.11 % to 9758.03 france 's cac closed 0.26 % lower at 4474.93 italy 's ftse mib was down 0.47 % at 21,294.34 spain 's ibex ended 0.42 % lower at 11,102.6 in the us , the dow jones industrial average is currently down 21 points or 0.13 % .
as for sterling , it stands at $ 1.6147 , down more than 1 % on the day albeit off its worst levels .
it fell a similar amount against the euro , falling to €1.24 .
on that note it 's time to shut up shop for the evening .
thanks for all your comments and we will be back tomorrow .

some of the scottish-linked companies have come back off their worst levels , notably royal bank of scotland after the announcement of further details of its plan to float its citizens business in the us .

but looking back at the worst levels of the leading companies in the ftse 100 which have links to scotland , and would therefore be hit by any yes vote in the independence referendum , there was some £ 5bn - £ 4.737bn to be accurate - wiped off their market value before the recovery .
worst , fairly obviously i suppose , were the banks , with rbs down £ 1.5bn and lloyds losing £ 1.85bn .

so the uk government , already reeling from the weekend 's polls which showed a yes vote was in the ascendence for the first time , was also looking at a near £ 1bn reduction in the value of its shares in the two state-controlled banks .

documents.title: forex.com : markets in panic mode over scotland
text: kathleen brooks , research director at forex.com , predicts that the pound could be in for a rough ride , whether the yes campaign are victorious or not .

she says : the market 's insecurities and concerns for an independent scotland means that the pound would be in the firing line if the yes campaign wins , however the pound could also be under pressure if the no vote win , but only by a small margin .
here 's kathleen 's takeaways : the markets are in panic mode , and starting to contemplate the prospect of a win for the yes vote .
even if the no campaign wins , we expect it to be by a very slim margin .

based on what happened in quebec in the 1990 's , even a win for the no campaign could have negative repercussions for some scottish companies and may not be that good for sterling in the medium-term .
we think that the outlook for gbp , especially versus the usd , looks bleak over the next 10 days to the referendum .
in gbp/usd $ 1.5722 is key support leading up to 18th sept. uk stocks are also likely to remain under pressure in the lead up to polling day .
the financial sector is particularly under pressure .
even a win for the no campaign could hurt scottish companies if it triggers capital and deposit flight .
on scotland 's sterlingisation option ( see 2.45pm ) , worth remembering that former brussels ' economics chief olli rehn warned last week that it would be incompatible with eu membership .
despite the late surge in support for the yes campaign , the bookmakers still believe scotland is more likely to vote no next week .
the two sides have narrowed , though , since sunday 's yougov opinion poll put the pro-independence side in the lead .
justin wolfers ( @ justinwolfers ) betting markets are n't buying into all the hype about scottish independence : no 71 % yes 29 %

documents.title: citi : markets wo n't be impressed if scotland renounces share of uk debt
text: jamie searle , fixed income specialist at citi has been answering a question about the implications of an independent scotland not taking its share of previous uk government debt - something salmond has threatened in the event westminster parties do not allow a currency union .
searle says there are future risks for an independent scotland if it does make such a refusal and if referendum day turns into default day '' .
in that case , scotland 's future funding costs would be affected .
he clarifies it would not be a default as such but certainly would be taken pretty negatively '' by capital markets .
and that 's the end of the citi conference call on scotland .
highlights start here .

documents.title: citi : sterlingisation option is most likely for independent scotland
text: citi 's top economists are now taking questions from investors on the scottish referendum ( conference call highlights start here ) .
my colleague katie allen reports : asked about what happens with scotland 's currency , economist michael saunders replies that so-called sterlingisation '' appears the most likely option .
in other words , saunders explains : the pound becomes legal tender in scotland and they would in effect be shadowing sterling allowing sterling to trade freely in the country . ''
there are two key problems with this , saunders says .
firstly , the lack of a lender of last resort , the role performed in the financial system at the moment by the bank of england .
secondly , there would be no backstop '' for sovereign debt .
he points out this set-up has precedents but that it has never been used in a country with anything like as large a banking system as scotland '' .
you would have to have doubts over the longevity of such an arrangement , '' saunders says .

jamie searle , from citi 's rates strategy team notes that the gilt markets ( where uk government debt is traded ) had until recently largely ignored the referendum based on poll suggesting a no vote .
now he says the referendum is too close to call '' and that the probability of a yes vote continues to rise '' .
talking about currencies , valentin marinov of citi global markets warns that investors should be cautious '' on the pound ahead of the referendum .
there is clear risk of further downside correction , '' he says .
that 's on top of today 's selloff which has knocked 1.75 cents off the pound .

documents.title: citi : scottish independence vote would affect interest rate hikes
text: michael saunders , citi 's head of european economics , says that the impact of a scottish yes vote for uk interest rates is by no means straight-forward .
he 's telling investors on today 's conference call that the referendum result would have implications for the bank of england 's rate-setting committee , the mpc .
saunders notes that the chance of a rate hike after a yes vote in the immediate aftermath of the referendum in october or november , would surely be very low '' .
beyond that it depends on the bank 's view over any deterioration in business confidence in the uk and also on any weakness in the pound .
the former could delay rate hikes , the latter could bring them forward .
the mpc will also have to consider to what extent any post-election fiscal tightening might be deferred as a result of a yes vote .
that might be a reason to be more hawkish '' , adds saunders .
( hawkish = keener to raise rates )
saunders finally moves onto implications for the rest of the uk in the event of a yes vote in scotland .

he notes sizeable implications '' on three points : trade and economy political position of the rest of the uk without scotland what the bank of england 's monetary policy committee would do to deal with the changes

documents.title: scotland 's four uncertainties
text: citi 's michael saunders is now outlining four key uncertainties for an independent scotland to investors : scotland 's relatively weak fiscal position scotland 's future currency position the position of the banking sector question of whether an independent scotland can or will be in the eu .
on the first point , he comments that scotland is highly dependent on oil and that oil revenues are not what they used to be '' .

documents.title: citi conference call on scottish independence : 'vote could go either way '
text: my colleague katie allen is on a conference call with economists at citi on the scottish referendum : economic and market consequences '' .

she reports that michael saunders , head of european economics at citi , began the call with an overview of polls and how they have changed , noting that until recently the polls showed a done deal '' and that it appeared the no vote was comfortably ahead '' .
but that has changed in the last week '' and the polls now show a statistical dead heat '' , he says .
from here the polls are looking too close to call .
this is one that could go either way . ''

saunders also notes that momentum appears to firmly with the yes vote '' and that turnout is likely to be a key deciding factor , with a high turnout suggesting more young people have voted and that in general they are more likely to vote yes to independence .
more to follow canary wharf in the docklands .
hawkes/getty images
sterling has also fallen sharply against the euro today .
the pound is currently down 1.1 % , or €0.135 , at €1.2469 .
that means one euro is worth 80.15p , up from 79.4p on friday night .
the city is deeply concerned by the uncertainty over what currency an independence scotland would use , and fears of currency flight if the 'yes ' campaign win , says brenda kelly of ig .
alex salmond has constantly insisted that the newly independent country will continue to use the pound in a currency union .
this has been ruled out by westminster , mainly because it is perceived as unreasonable that taxpayers in wales and england should support scotland 's financial sector and public deficit .
there is an option to simply continue to use sterling without the backing of the bank of england .
bear in mind that having the central bank available as a lender of last resort is only really pertinent during a significant financial crisis .
mark carney has pledged to fulfil this role in the transition period .
but what would a transition period look like and how long would it actually be expected to last ?
the prospect of exiting the pound could trigger bank runs as savers attempt to protect their deposits .
banks based in scotland are widely expected to move down south and thus this significant flow of capital leaving scotland would do no good to the scottish economy . ''

documents.title: shares and pound hit by scottish independence prospects
text: the prospect of scotland voting for independence in 10 days time has provoked a flurry of alarm in the financial markets today .
the pound has taken a severe buffeting , to levels not seen since november 2013 .
it 's down almost two cents against the us dollar at $ 1.6143 , extending last week 's losses as the yes campaign surged in the polls .

pound vs dollar during september 2014 reuters oliver harvey , foreign exchange strategist at deutsche bank , says the british public establishment is reacting with rising panic '' to sunday 's yougov poll .
he believes a 'yes ' vote on 18 september could derail the uk economic recovery .

on the currency side , it could at worse lead to a destabilizing crisis in the whole british banking system and at best leave the the rest of the uk with an unstable currency union in which the bank of england is forced to continue to provide liquidity to scottish banks while westminster thrashes out a fiscal and monetary arrangement with a new scottish sovereign government holding all the cards . ''
the blue-chip ftse 100 index has also been hit , led by two scottish-based banks .
lloyds banking group are down by 3.3 % , wiping £ 1.74bn off its value .
royal bank of scotland have shed 2.8 % , or £ 1.1bn .
energy firm sse and standard life have both lost £ 400m , babcock is down £ 233m , weir group down £ 100m and aberdeen asset management off by £ 82m .
in total , more than £ 4bn has been knocked off those seven company 's value .
ftse 100 biggest fallers today .
reuters as alastair mccaig , market analyst at ig puts it : not since 1977 and the infamous wembley pitch invasion have scots caused so much carnage to london .
a protest at the annual thessaloniki international fair on september 6 , 2014 , where prime minister samaras declared that greece 's wounds are healing .
mitrolidis/afp/getty images over in greece , prime minister antonis samaras 's promise of tax cuts and growth this year have failed to wow his critics .

instead of appreciation or even enthusiasm that their worst slump in modern times was about to be consigned to the dustbin of history , greek unions responded with a large dose of cynicism and disbelief .

from athens , helena smith reports : the prime minister 's statements are far removed from the reality in which most greeks are forced to survive , '' odysseus trivalas , who presides over the greek civil servants ' union , adedy , told the guardian .

the reality is that nearly two million are unemployed , 6,500 have taken their own lives , pensions and wages have been cut dramatically , insurance funds are collapsing and people are losing their jobs .
these cuts , which would n't even take effect until 2016-1017 , bear no connection to any of that . ''

instead , trivalas echoed widespread sentiment that with the ruling conservative party lagging behind syriza , the radical left main opposition party in polls , samaras ' nostrums were a political ruse aimed squarely at boosting the government 's standing ahead of possible early elections .

the threat of greece being plunged into renewed political turmoil has mounted as speculation grows that it may well be forced to hold early elections if the ruling coalition , now clinging to power with a majority of two , fails to garner enough votes to replace the country 's outgoing president , karolos papoulias , when his term ends next february .
trivalas added : we all believe that elections will be early and this is part of blackmailing greeks into thinking that this government not only offers stability but something even better .
nothing could be further from the truth . ''
greece is believed to have wanted to make tax relief a central platform of talks when negotiations were re-launched with its troika '' of creditors at the eu , ecb and imf in paris last week .

lenders preferred , instead , to focus on athens ' implementations of long overdue structural reforms - the price of 240 bn euro in emergency bailout loans with all talk of tax breaks being rebuffed .
in his enthusiasm to win political capital , samaras had announced the cuts without even having them approved , trivalas quipped .

documents.title: lagarde urges germany to do more to help eurozone
text: imf managing director christine lagarde .
lo scalzo/epa christine lagarde , head of the international monetary fund , is going round europe trying to stir up enthusiasm for a german investment splurge to help the eurozone .
the imf chief has held a series of press interviews , saying that germany could help its the region by boosting its spending - and also backing calls for structural reforms across the euro area .

reuters has the details : lagarde told daily les echos in an interview the process could be aided by germany , which is borrowing at record-low rates and on track to record a public sector surplus for the third year running .
we think that public or private investment ( in germany ) to finance infrastructure would be welcome , '' she said , stressing this did not mean making the german economy less competitive .

asked in a second interview on radio classique whether germany could do more to spur a european economic recovery , lagarde told the radio : it seems to us at the international monetary fund that it ( germany ) can go a bit further , that it can do a bit more , in germany 's interest . ''
last week , ecb chief mario draghi urged eurozone governments to make structural reforms ; seen as a pointed reminder to paris and rome to crack on .

lagarde today backed that call , telling radio classique that european governments must make themselves more competitive , with more flexible labour markets i think structural reform is necessary in terms of labour market regulations , excessive regulations in some areas , of areas of economic activity that are too protected and which need to be opened up to competition.this goes for everyone it 's true for france , it 's true for germany , it 's true for italy . ''

documents.title: ireland wants to repay imf loans early
text: dublin city hall .
mcphee/guardian ireland 's finance minister michael noonan begins a long week of lobbying across europe this week .
he 's starting today in brussels where he will ask eu partners if the republic can pay off its debts to the international monetary fund first , before tackling its obligations to europe .

henry mcdonald , ireland correspondent , has the details : noonan and the fine gael-labour coalition believe that if ireland is allowed to repay the imf bailout bill first before paying back loans from the european central bank it could result in annual savings of €375m to the irish exchequer .

his logic is that with ireland now enjoying low borrowing costs on the international markets -a sign of renewed global investors ' confidence in the republic - dublin should be allowed to go first to the private markets to pay off the imf side of the debt .
the imf debt burden is greater than that ireland owes to the ecb .
the irish finance minister 's marathon round of meetings includes one with mario draghi , the ecb 's chief ahead of a meeting of all the eu finance ministers in milan on friday .

the eu 's response to noonan 's request will show if the praise european partners have been lavishing on ireland for accepting austerity ( the poster boys of europe and all that in contrast with recalcitrant greeks and spaniards ) was just for the optics .
a deal for noonan is critical too as he charts the october budget which will be crucial in determining the fortunes of the current government with an election less than two years away .
the recent surge of money into eurozone government bonds has driven down the yield , or interest rate , on ireland 's 10-year debt to just 1.65 % .
that 's much less than the cost of its rescue loans .
and irish two-year bond yields are negative , meaning investors are now paying for the privilege of holding ireland 's short-term debt .
victoria fritz ( @ vfritznews ) currency trader tells me that selling off the pound is like shooting ducks in a barrel today .
`` wonderful few hours '' of trade , he says

documents.title: sterling selloff accelerates ; pound down two cents against the dollar
text: the selloff in sterling has deepened , as scottish independence jitters reverberate around the financial markets .
the pound is down two cents against the us dollar , to $ 1.6118 , cementing its position as the weakest major currency today .
that 's a new 10-month low .

pound vs us dollar , august 2013-august 2014 reuters fears over the future of its banking sector , its currency options , and how much uk debt an independent scotland would take on are all pushing sterling down .
alistair cotton , corporate trader at currencies direct , reckons the pound would slump by at least 5 % more if scotland votes yes '' on 18 september .
the rationale behind scotland continuing to use the pound is to promote stability and remove uncertainty for trade .
domestically that might be true , but internationally the opposite is happening .
markets do n't like uncertainty .
we can expect at least a 5 % drop in the pound in the face of yes vote - and it could be considerably more .
the prospect of protected negotiations will create a period of volatility in exchange rates , bonds and equities which will continue until concrete decisions over debt and currency are made .
capital flight is the main concern for an independent scotland , as financial firms will want the safe harbour the bank of england provides .
we can expect large financial firms to all move headquarters to england .
whatever decision scotland makes on 18 september we can expect to see short to medium-term pain across the british isles . ''

documents.title: eurozone recession fears grow as confidence tumbles
text: this is worrying .
economic confidence in the eurozone has fallen sharply , as the european central bank 's efforts to stimulate growth and inflation fail to calm the region .
the sentix research group reported that morale among investors slumped this month , to -9.8 on its index .

that 's the lowest reading since july 2013 , and a big drop on august 's 2.7.. sentix said the collapse came despite new measures taken by the european central bank '' , which announced a qe-style asset purchase scheme last week .

the current situation measure , and investors ' 6-month expectations , both fell into negative territory , the group said , adding : that 's remarkable because ever since president ( mario ) draghi took office , the ecb has always managed to boost investors ' economic expectations with a variety of measures .
this does n't seem to be working anymore . ''
the indicator points to another recession in the euro zone , '' it added .
the report is online here .

documents.title: brent oil price falls below $ 100
text: the oil price has just slipped to its lowest level in 14 months .
the cost of a barrel of brent crude is changing hands for $ 99.96 per barrel , the first time below the $ 100 mark since june 2013 .

an unexpected fall in chinese imports ( data released overnight ) is one factor , as is the pound 's weakness against the us dollar ( as oil is priced in dollars , even if it 's sourced from the north sea )
british banks have been warned against dodging the eu 's bank bonus cap .

michel barnier , a vice-president of the european commission , has threatened the city with a a co-ordinated policy response '' , if they circumvent rules banning staff from bonuses worth more than 100 % of base salary , or 200 % with shareholders ' permission .
more here : eu moves to crackdown on banks dodging bonus cap

documents.title: spanish house prices rise for first time since 2008
text: while britain 's housing boom slows , spain 's long property slump may be over .
house prices in spain rose by 0.8 % year-on-year in the second quarter of 2014 , the first annual rise since the financial crisis began six years ago .

the national statistics institute reported that the prices of newly built houses led the way , up 1.9 % , while second-hand '' houses rose 0.2 % , the highest increase since the fourth quarter of 2007 .
spanish house prices .
spain 's housing market boomed during the early days of the eurozone , fuelled by easy credit flowing to the periphery .
its implosion left its banks nursing huge losses , forcing spain to take rescue funds from the eu .
more here ( pdf )
the pound 's 1 % tumble against the us dollar makes it the worst performing major currency today .

fastft adds : if one includes exotic , tiny currencies then only the afghan afghani , sierra leone 's leone , the tongan pa'aanga , the vanuatu vatu and the malawi kwacha have done worse than sterling today , according to bloomberg data .
here 's another sign that britain 's housing market may be easing : more than half of the most expensive houses put up for sale in london recently have been withdrawn , due to weak demand .

the financial times reports : tax rises on high-value properties , along with the prospect of a mansion tax '' and the uncertainty caused by a looming general election , have made homes that are worth more than £ 2m much harder to sell , according to research for the financial times .

more than half of all properties in london 's most expensive central areas have been withdrawn unsold in the six months to the end of june , the research by the property data company lonres and analysts dataloft shows .

documents.title: rbs , sse and lloyds shares hit by scottish independence poll
text: the surge of support for scottish independence has sent jitters through the stock market this morning .

shares in companies with large scottish interest suffered sharp falls in early trading , my colleague fiona walsh reports : royal bank of scotland was the biggest faller in the ftse 100 , falling more than 3 % in early trading .
energy group sse ( scottish & southern electricity ) were down 2.5 % , lloyds banking group dropped 2.2 % , standard life were down 2 % and aberdeen asset management fell 1.5 % .
the ftse 100 , which last week reached a 14 year high , was down 18 points , at 6837 .
michael hewson ( @ mhewson cmc ) biggest fallers today on # ftse , standard life , lloyds , rbs , babcock , scottish and southern and weir group in wake of w/e # indyref poll
halifax also flags up that britain is ( not before time ) building more homes .
although probably not at a fast enough rate to tackle the demand shortages .
the number of new homes built in april-june was 7 % higher than in the same period last year , it reports .
a continuation of this upward trend in housebuilding could also help to bring demand and supply into better balance .
and home sales remain broadly stable so far this year '' , at between 101,000 and 104,000 a month ( apart from february which hit 109,500 ) .
a survey released last week , though , found that construction firms were struggling to lay their hands on skilled workers and raw materials
despite august 's slowdown , house prices are still up by 3.0 % over the last quarter , according to halifax 's survey .

halifax 's monthly data can be a little erratic , but howard archer of ihs global insight reckons a slowdown is underway : the halifax data tie in with our view that house prices will keep on clearly rising overall through the coming months , but at a more restrained rate .
shaun richards ( @ notayesmansecon ) halifax : annually , house prices were 9.7 % higher in the three months to august than in the same three months last year

documents.title: uk house price growth slows
text: after a strong run , britain 's housing market took a breather last month with prices barely rising .
halifax 's monthly survey of the sector found that prices inched up by just 0.1 % in august , sharply down on the 1.2 % recorded in july .
on an annual basis , prices are up 9.7 % compared to august 2013 , down from the rollicking 10.2 % surge recorded the previous month .
halifax house prices , to august 2014 .
recent affordability tests , and the prospect of the bank of england raising interest rates soon , may be weighing on the market , leading to a summer lull .
weak wage growth , with pay packets failing to match inflation , may also be hurting demand for houses .

as martin ellis , halifax 's housing economist , puts it : earnings growth that remains below consumer price inflation , and the prospect of an interest rate rise at some point over the coming months , are likely to curb demand .
ellis also suggests that more second-hand houses are coming on to the market , which could make some impact on britain 's chronic supply shortages .
reaction to follow

documents.title: introduction
text: good morning , and welcome to our rolling coverage of the financial markets , the economy , the eurozone and business .
coming up today a new house price survey from the halifax building society will show whether britain 's housing boom is running out of steam .
sterling is taking a pounding this morning after the yes campaign took the lead in the scottish independence campaign , just 10 days before the vote .

the pound has tumbled by 1.5 cents against the us dollar to its lowest level since november , as i 've written up here : pound slumps to 10-month low after scottish yes campaign takes poll lead a traditional sailing vessel flying yes campaign emblazoned saltires sailing past the forth rail bridge in the firth of forth .
macleod in the corporate world we 'll be looking at the latest results from associated british foods - the firm behind primark .
and sweden 's electrolux has just announced a $ 3.3bn deal to buy general electric 's appliances business .
in the eurozone , we 'll be digesting greek prime minister antonis samaras 's pledge of tax cuts this year , as greece 's long slump comes to an end .

while germany has reported strong trade data , suggesting that its economy is up ( more on this shortly ) and the long-running battle between chancellor george osborne and the eu over capping bankers ' bonuses will come to a head today at the european court of justice .
